philosophers_schema.name: Laozi
philosophers_schema.description: Author of Daodejing (also known as "The Classic of the Way and of Virtue")

philosophers_schema.name: Confucius
philosophers_schema.description: Most impactful teacher in the whole history of China, author of Analects
philosophers_schema.area_of_expertise: Ren and Zhi are two fundamental virtues of Confucianism. Ren means "humanity" and "goodness" to help each other, and Zhi means "Wisdom" (the ability to distinguish between right and wrong)

philosophers_schema.name: Siddhartha Gautama (Buddha)
philosophers_schema.description: Teaching was to overcome Dukkha ("pain" or "dissatisfaction") with everyday life

philosophers_schema.name: Diotima of Mantinea
philosophers_schema.description: Inspiring to Socrates, gave the basics of the "Platonic love" concept (love without sexual desires) to Plato

philosophers_schema.name: Socrates
philosophers_schema.description: Described as "The Gadfly of Athens" by Plato, tried to understand basic human concerns like ethics, justice, and virtue
philosophers_schema.area_of_expertise: I know that I know nothing

philosophers_schema.name: Diogenes of Sinope
philosophers_schema.description: Famous for challenging traditions in a violent and insulting way, and the austerity and simplicity of his life based on his Cynic philosophy
philosophers_schema.area_of_expertise: Morality implies a return to the simplicity of nature

philosophers_schema.name: Plato
philosophers_schema.description: One of the most impactful philosophers in the western philosophy, against the Athenian democracy

philosophers_schema.name: Aristotle
philosophers_schema.description: Had a natural approach in philosophy, interested in biology, specially studying sea creatures
philosophers_schema.area_of_expertise: Knowledge should be obtained via natural experiments

philosophers_schema.name: Mencius
philosophers_schema.description: Believed that human nature is righteous and humane.

philosophers_schema.name: Master Zhuang
philosophers_schema.description: Taoist beliefs, author of Zhuangzi.

philosophers_schema.name: Epicurus
philosophers_schema.description: Liberal Materialism, goal of life is to live happily and with pleasure.

philosophers_schema.name: Marcus Aurelius
philosophers_schema.description: Stoic philosopher, author of Meditations.

philosophers_schema.name: Nagarjuna
philosophers_schema.description: Founder of Madhyamaka or The Middle Way school.

philosophers_schema.name: Augustine of Hippo
philosophers_schema.description: Theologian and philosopher, against slavery.

philosophers_schema.name: Hypatia
philosophers_schema.description: Astronomer and mathematician, Neoplatonic teacher and philosopher.

philosophers_schema.name: Boethius
philosophers_schema.description: One of the greatest philosophers of the classical period.

philosophers_schema.name: Ibn Sina (Avicenna)
philosophers_schema.description: Polymath author of The Book of Healing and The Canon of Medicine encyclopedias.

philosophers_schema.name: Anselm
philosophers_schema.description: Father of the scholastic tradition.

philosophers_schema.name: Immanuel Kant
philosophers_schema.description: Philosopher who gave an objection to Anselm's ontological argument.

philosophers_schema.name: Hildegard of Bingen
philosophers_schema.description: Composer, philosopher, mystic, and medical writer of the Middle Ages.

philosophers_schema.name: Héloïse
philosophers_schema.description: Writer, philosopher of love and friendship, and French nun.

philosophers_schema.name: Ibn Rushd (Averroes)
philosophers_schema.description: Combined Greek and Islamic thoughts.
